message.content: nice! now, context compression of the nexus session is done by me, but I'll increasingly look for help from you in this, given your existing direct role in session management and comms. The message used post-context clear to reload state and context seems to be very effective (I tried a few variants before settling on this) - can you record it, for use when we need to advise other agents you are in comms with of the same? Use the standard message format, then the text I used above just replacing the specifc agent name to match the @TO portion. (I.e. I should probably have started mine "@ADMIN -> @NEXUS: @gov/context_comp..."). I'm imagining we'll need a library of message templates like this for specific use cases - basic agent integrity checks, work checkins, instructing on upcoming external compression, etc

message.content: @ADMIN -> @NEXUS: great, thanks :) we're going to hold off on all of this for a minute and redirect a bit now. firstly, I have an idea that may improve session identification - it's really simple - you generate a fairly random string, send it to a tmux window (or just output it in your own, for self id) then grep for it in all nexus/sessions (may need to backoff/retry, can be delays in jsonl file writes, I've noticed). Your own sessionId should have changed compared to last records, as I've exiting & re-opened the claude code cli for this interaction. If you think this approach is valid, would you like to try it out, collecting findings (and any other notes worth recording) in your scratch.md?

message.content: I'm thinking there will be a script in project root - `./run.sh init`, which I start in window 0 / admin (sorry, you'll be moved to window 1), which requires running inside tmux (assumed env `cd ~/prj/rtfw; tmux -f ./tmux.conf`). The script pauses and tells its user (me) to start up and validate nexus. When I confirm, it does `tmux send-keys -t 1 'please run @nexus/agent_bootstrap_process.md'`, `tmux send-keys -t 1 Enter`, or something (the doc will contain your own instructions here). Then I do `./run.sh monitor` which just does infinite loop sleep / check bell or idle on you / `tmux send-keys -t 1 'please run @nexus/main_loop.md'`, or something. I can just ^C that to suspend the loop if I want, and you intelligently know where I'm looking. Next phase - I can type out messages that get sent to you as @ADMIN -> @NEXUS: (message), and you can echo stuff back there for me to see / respond to.

message.content: @ADMIN -> @NEXUS: [MAIN LOOP]: you actually don't need to worry about active windows - they are working away and need not be interrupted. you want to look for bells (often indicates approval required for tool use, or end_turn) and silence (in practice this shouldn't happen without bell first, I *think*). If you have messages to send to agent, this is the time to send them. If none, agent should be prompted to reflect (as you've just done), then maybe if still nothing we may need a new process to clear and temp. disable their silence flag, until another agent sends message to them at which point we re-enable silence flag? Let's think about how this works holistically?

message.content: nice! next, I'd like us to think hard about how this all fits together into the larger system. Your messaging and session / window management is seeming really solid now, but we have really tried using the main loop approach fully as yet. In order to get there, I'd like to first more clearly define the bigger picture and session flow. In short - 1. agent started / resumed / just underwent context compression, is waiting for input. 2. we prompt it for first/next step (i.e. if post-compression, give them @gov/context_compression_protocol.md and ask to load reload required context). This must always re-affirm their AGENT name and role as both the TO and @AGENT.md . 3. regular main loop - I think this requires significant review and simplification next (prompt -> agent does stuff (with tool approvals if needed) -> read only final output, repeat). 4. We'll get you to detect when context compression needed and manage that in-line. I'm think that all agent's input & output will consist entirely of comms_protocol following messages (which you're doing awesomely at for your output to me), exception for input if @ADMIN is sending direct inputs like I'm doing now as I type reaaaalllyy slowly compared to you lot ;) Let's work on this in a new doc perhaps, for either reference from or insertion into your context.md

message.content: I see the problem here - the Enter to submit the prompt didn't go through, the input box is still active in that window. The reason this happens is that the final string on the input is and @file link, which causes a little auto-complete file select helper to show up and it swallows the first Enter. we can either do Enter twice, or re-arrange the prompt wording so that the file link comes earlier. I'd used this one with you previously, which would't have that issue, and seemed to work well - "@ADMIN -> @NEXUS: @gov/context_compression_protocol.md completed for @NEXUS.md - please reload all relevant agent context for continuation", but we'll need to ensure that the same issue doesn't occur in other situations anyway. A single trailing space would actually do the trick. (nb. I've cleared input field on gov now if you want to try it again)
